author: @GaryWilliamsJr
text:
Olay, I don't know if you will see this but I'm from Baltimore and can give you what's going on here. 

Mayor Scott has some progressive instincts. However, the biggest donors in Baltimore are real estate developers. These folks want a heavy police presence. Secondly, there are some older Black voters who want heavier police presence. These folks vote often. That Gen X and Boomer Black voting bloc are very very active here. While overall, most residents side eye the police, the actual consistent voting demos want more police. Our turnout is low but the demos that want the police actually show up at the polls. Brandon feels compelled to respond to that.

The other thing about Baltimore is that the relationship with the city and the rest of the state is super contentious. White folks in the suburbs literally say that they gave Black folks the city and we supposedly ruined it. However that's not it actually went down. And so there is pressure from the state for Baltimore to "do something". Especially because white folks are starting to come back into the city and these people want to feel safe, despite the fact that it's poor black folks who are overwhelming victims of crime here. 

Hopefully that's helpful

replies.author: @akinyiomer4589
replies.text:
‚Äã@iamzojr1 Please explain what you mean - by giving examples or anything you feel that helps illustrate your point - by the "emasculation" point you made. 

How and why do you feel emasculated when black women do things to uplift themselves and their communities?

And on a very serious note, you mention that black men find it hard to explain what they're struggling with without being gaslit with terms like "patriarchy" or "toxic masculinity". Can you give us an example, again take all the time and space you need to illustrate what you mean - of what this looks like? Because to me if I hear that someone is trying to express something and that person keeps being called out in terms that were meant to bring awareness to a type of social inequality or power structure ... especially if that person _is_ a said member of traditionally more powerful group ... then baby. 

A little critical thinking has to be done to ensure you're not acting similarly to a white person who may not have done anything heinous in their life, but they're feeling attacked/judged/uncomfortable because people are calling out how twisted the status quo is for the first time. 

Those people who were shouting "all lives matter!" had genuine anxiety, worry and _anger_ because their racist thinking _felt_ to them that black people wanting equality of dignity for their lives = black people want supremacy the way we've practised supremacy. They couldn't even comprehend it as a shot for equality because they assumed in order to lift black people up, you had to crush other races - and more specifically the white race. That's how they understood it and that's why they went nuts.

So I am seriously asking you ... with all that considered ... when you say you are being gaslit by shouts of toxic masculinity and the patriarchy ... is there any merit to those criticisms when you take a sec to think about it? Is there any way the anguish you're feeling is similar to what some white people are going through?

Because it does not make sense that women fighting for equality automatically means men are put down. How _exactly_ does black women uplifting each other _emasculate_ ... i.e. strip you of your masculinity?

replies.author: @thonrich5596
replies.text:
I agree that black women have to diminish themselves in society a lot to mitigate the effects of racism and sexism. In this case, I think the lack of a black women agenda is the perception of black women that Kamala Harris, by virtue of her identity, will advocate for black women once in office. Black men don‚Äôt have the same confidence. Remember, Joe Biden has to promise a black woman on the Supreme Court and an ended up picking a black woman as VP. I suspect that if Harris had a black man as VP, these complaints wouldn‚Äôt be as loud. I also suspect that if Harris wasn‚Äôt the choice after Biden exited, and it was Gavin Newsome, Black women would demand more in terms of an agenda/representation.

For the record, I think representation in the place of actual policy commitments is part of why we don‚Äôt get what we need from democrats.

replies.author: @iamzojr1
replies.text: @akinyiomer4589what‚Äôs understood doesn‚Äôt need to be explained. I can explain until I‚Äôm blue in the face. You‚Äôll more than likely listen to respond and not to understand. It is what it is. At the end of the day, men and women don‚Äôt share similar ideologies for the most part

replies.author: @akinyiomer4589
replies.text:
@iamzojr1  That's the thing. You purposely haven't tried to explain anything in this entire thread, not even just to me but anyone in-thread. Not even when asked to clarify even once. 

People are trying to give you the benefit of the doubt and asking you to expand. You are in a social-justice/political-consciousness aware space, we're not representative of the general public. 

Everyone here has had to - at some point - articulate exactly what the f**k injustice they either personally faced or witnessed happening to someone else. As a black man you should goddamn know, considering the type of pain and frustration you've probably been through in your life, there's no faking or hiding oppression. Even when people try to sugar coat it or deny it because it doesn't suit them - it comes out regardless.

I'm sorry but your response really is the icing on the cake for most people here: you either have nothing of merit to bring as a genuine argument or you know full well you're gonna be on the wrong side of sexism if you say it the way you wanna say it. 

And instead of maybe doing the work and looking at your own prejudices that's making you feel this aggrieved, you're persevering - like anyone who is moving through the world with any type of prejudice - with that aggrieved anger and maybe only letting it out in spaces where you know people will be like-minded. And doing this haughty "y'all don't understand me!" thing to ramp up the faux victimhood. 

Fam lemme tell you: even when women were being denied even basic shit like legal access to their own money, systematic oppression in the workplace, systematic sexual harassment and rape culture in all spheres of life: we could always fucking articulate the wrong-ness that was done to us because it existed. We didn't shake our heads and say in a moody, mysterious way "you won't get it so I wont even bother" the way a moody teenager gets when they think they're being all misunderstood by their parents. Fuck no! That shit was excruciating for real! All of our grievances were uncomfortable for the world to hear because they were real and they exploded out of us. And most of all our grievances were not like, Hitleresque: "well I'm burdened with this but it's because of this OTHER group of people and their inherent evil or fickleness that they stop me from succeeding." 

I think that's why you know it's futile to bring up what you really wanna say in this space specifically. 

Tbh dude if I'm right, I can't stress enough how much you need to dig deep and work on those prejudices. You think you're fine now but if you let it fester you'll find that hate and disdain will show up in other ways that'll leave any political-consciousness you have feeling hollow. Mark Robinson is an ultra-extreme version of this, like so ultra it's not even funny. But there are millions of POC men that'll happily be involved in the oppression of women because it makes them feel a little better even while they're being oppressed under a more powerful structure. Honestly good luck.

replies.text: @ariel0042¬† i think that is only true when it's true tho. The SPECIFIC needs that men and boys have that are different than the needs of women are not met by uplifting women. replies.author: @nickmaxx
replies.text:
‚Äã‚Äã‚Äã@AquaMarineFBVA it absolutely can though! 

If you believe that poor performance in school is brought by parental neglect due to increasing economic difficulty, then lifting families such that parents have job security, and higher wages will give them more time and stability to give young black boys the time and attention they need from their parents when developing.

Subsiding the cost of child care will give them more support, allowing working parent housholds to be able to ensure that _someone_ can care for their young children while they work.

If lack of opportunity for younger black men in the workforce is a problem, then investing in small businesses can provide more opportunities for these young men to find avenues of employment. Investing in subsidizing trade education, and investing in reducing the cost of higher education can give them more career pathways.

Investing in improving public school funding can ensure that more people have access to better primary and secondary education.

Investing in reducing the cost and increasing availability of healthcare for everyone will help black men find mental health care. Investing in  reducing the cost of healthcare professional education and training will make it easier for black men to become health care professionals so they can provide better care to other black men.

Most of this isn't even specific to black people or black men, policies that help working class people of all walks will definitely help black men. Its about reading between the lines and understanding how social economics comes back and helps us. Our needs ain't that different.

author: @tacrewgirl
text:
I enjoy these weekly panelists. Thanks Olay for sharing your group of friends with us. I appreciate the discourse.

Looking forward to your video - The Seven Really Sins of Black Politicians.

Sadly, we know that if Black candidates center Black issues that becomes a thing and detracts from their campaign. However if a non-Black candidate does it, "they care". The only exceptions seem to be when if a city is predominantly Black.

Laughing about how MLK's I Have a Dream speech would be received during the age of socy media. That was hilarious. Honestly that would be a great video topic to show how social  media has hurt certain causes. Would the Civil Rights Movement have been able to have the same momentum and outcome with social media or the state of current society.

46:20 - Great point about how social media created a rise of contrarians and those monetizing their pro-Blackness. In and of itself is not bad, but the book Elite Capture shows the essence of this.

author: @ImaginosWorkshop
text: We as a people vote then that's it. I'm all for intellectualizing and I see people like yourselves putting in work. However, we have to create institutions within the black community that 1. Can focus our economic power to more effectively lobby for what we want 2. Stay vigilant that these institutions aren't cooped. ie no preachers. 3. Though we aren't a monolith we are bound by trauma and struggle so we need to agree on a platform and move on that. 4  We also need to stop confusing comfort with gains. We have been lulled to sleep by this false sense of inclusion. We aren't included where it counts and that's access to real power. 5. While on paper intersectionality is great it adds or numbers and voice to movements that in the end benefit our "allies" but never seem to benefit us as a people. I think maybe we should demand more from these allies for our help.

author: @ObsidianLife
text:
Olay is on point as usual!  Mad respect.

I think the one thing that I feel isn‚Äôt brought up enough (This is not targeting anybody on the panel) Is the casual racism of how the Obama thing worked, and that Obama played into it, as he always does. If Obama decides to speak to ‚Äúmen‚Äú in general and tell them to stop being sexist/misogynist assholes then that would‚Äôve gotten the message across. The fact that he went out of his way to target black men under the pretense that they are more misogynistic than anybody else is the obnoxious part.  Now to be clear, I‚Äôve met many subpar black men who are definitely sexist, bigoted and generally awful people‚Ä¶ But as 12 to 14% of the population, we are not the SOURCE of the issue. It also speaks volumes that the Dems ignore the entire Manosphere and pretend that misogyny more of a black thing than a white thing.  Either blame men or don't, Liberals and the DNC need to stop pretend like black men are the source and look in the mirror. 

Now to the point‚Ä¶ A lot of the subpar Blackman who jump up and grab the mic (Myron Gaines or Tate types and their wannabes) are desperate for attention and extremely vocal. It‚Äôs kind of like the standard Trump supporter‚Ä¶ It‚Äôs not that they‚Äôre that many of them, it‚Äôs that they come out and grab the mic anytime they get a chance.  I think they are overrepresented in terms of how they react and respond to this type of thing‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm willing to bet that if a white guy came out and said the exact same thing Obama said then the comments would skew more towards worthwhile black men who would take offense as opposed to the sellouts‚Ä¶ IMO‚Ä¶

author: @joeshmoe4062
text: Respectfully, I have not found any historical merit for there being a black male patriarchy in the U.S. at least empirically, as a matter of fact sociologist Raewyn Connell who is known for her research of hegemonic masculinity, says that black men exist outside of that and that it has been the decolonization efforts of black men worldwide and not feminism, that has been the biggest threat to western patriarchy.

replies.author: @joeshmoe4062
replies.text: @LoudReed I research almost every day, the more I do, I see evidence to the contrary, black men have been the most progressive group of men in U.S. history.

replies.author: @joeshmoe4062
replies.text: @LoudReed I research almost every day to one degree or another, and from what I‚Äôve found black men have been the most egalitarian group of men in U.S. history and have always been very supportive of black women‚Äôs concerns and interests. Finally, when people say black men simply mimic their oppressor, it reminds me of what Samuel Cartwright and first wave feminists argued, which was black women were better as slaves to white men rather than wives of black men, because of their tyrannical and savage nature as a degraded form of men, it‚Äôs like saying the white racist were right.

replies.author: @k-sama9963
replies.text: I think you‚Äôd find value studying more about intersectionality to help you with that. Around race and sex and the impact it has  in the black community. Major issues include black men aligning with the privileges patriarchy offers over black liberation. A lot of what you see can be considered parallel attempts to present woman as masculine  black woman or emasculate fellow black men who don‚Äôt meet a certain criteria is exactly what slaves did, to maintain order and power. You can definitely see parallels, for many conquering was the first interaction with power. I think these themes could help you see more about black patriarchy. While not on top within this system black men are still over someone and many fight to maintain that status quo. Good luck with your search !
